comments.text:
As +SilverGravity said you need to fix both. Unfixed males become 
territorial and mark everywhere and females make a terrible caterwauling 
type noise when they're in heat (the sound attracts other males closer to 
your home too). If you fix the female and not the male he may try to mate 
with her when she is unwilling resulting in fighting and if your male is 
fixed but your female isn't your male may go after the female in 
frustration to try to make her stop making the annoying sounds and gestures 
of a cat in heat. The unfixed cat will eventually attempt to escape (the 
male will escape in search of females and the female in search of males). 
Get both fixed pronto. Look up programs in your area or speak to your vet.
comments.author: MissLilyputt

comments.text:
Both. Males will spray and try and mate, which is actually painful for the 
female, plus trying to escape, and the females will cry constantly. Though,

more issues. We had to separate my cats for a few days because they weren't 
fixed yet, so it's best to do it early on.

Thank you for rescuing them! First please make sure you get them 
spayed/neutered and taken to the vet at least once for vaccinations and 
deworming treatment. Some shelters and rescues host low cost vet clinics 
and you can recoup some of the cost through responsible adoption fees. 

What do you mean by how to be a cat? You want them to be friendly toward 
humans and used to the home environment, you just need to take them inside 
and play with them and pet them individually each day. Most other aspects 
of "being a cat" will come naturally to them, hunting, grooming, using the 
litter box, climbing, sratching, etc. Their siblings will teach them 
socialization with other cats and not to bite too hard.  

WHEN they are vaccinated and given the medical clear, it's helpful to have 
them play with a friendly adult cat who can provide them advanced training 
in the ways of the cat.

comments.text:
The only 'health risks' to keeping a male dog intact are testicular cancer 
and prostate issues. Testicular cancer is so rare that it is pretty much 
not an issue. Prostate issues are more common, but those can be solved by 
neutering WHEN the issue arrises.

There are health issues with neutering dogs. They are a lot more prone to 
bone cancer, which is a very scary type of cancer. They are also more prone 
to obesity and other health issues.

There is no proof that neutering decreases aggression in dogs, territorial 
or otherwise. The only behavioural issue it has been proven to decrease is 
roaming.

This Facebook group has a lot of info on the downsides of spaying and 
neutering dogs: 
https://www.facebook.com/groups/alternativealteringinfo/?fref=ts
Check the files, you can find links to some interesting studies done on 
this (like the golden retriever study). You can also read about the 
alternatives, like vasectomies.

Spaying and neutering dogs is NOT a black and white issue.

comments.text:
*warning: long* I see your point, and I get why you object altering the 
animals for the owner's convenience, however these 2 surgeries really are 
not the same. When you declaw a cat, you're not removing their *need* to 
scratch. The mechanism, the instinct to use their claws is still there - 
they just don't have the body part to perform it, which causes physical and 
psychological damage. When you neuter a cat - you take away their *need* to 
mate. The sexual equivalent of declawing, would be to leave your cat all 
horny, but somehow make it impossible for him to get a hard-on... The 
instinct is still there, just not the tool. And let it be said, that I do 
see how the topic of neutering an indoor cat is somewhat controversial, 
(and i really detest it when people say they "fixed" their cat, or "had it 
done". If you decide to do it - ok, but call it what it is: Neutering. It's 
a surgery. It's not like having your ears pierced.). There are many reasons 
for it, specially in areas that have so many strays they cause the 
extinction of other species (birds, fish). Also - do not project human sex 
onto cats. Cats don't mate with the thought of babies in their mind, they 
don't feel intimate with the other cat or form a family unit. In fact, a 
tomcat could easily attack his own kittens, thinking they are prey and 
breeders keep the kittens away from their dad if he appears too predatory 
like around them. Cats mate, because they go into heat, and the only relief 
is mating. They don't have sex for the pleasure of it - when in heat a 
female needs to mate once for the heat cycle to be over (since it often 
takes once for her to get pregnant). Cats do not connect their cat-pride to 
birthing kittens. Their essence is hunting, being territorial and dominant. 
A neutered male will sometimes mount a female, to display dominance, he 
will still spray, if he senses trespassers, and hunt and play. Neutering a 
cat is not the same as neutering a human - they do not have the array of 
emotions connected to the act like we do.

But still, why not just leave the cat the way he way nature intended? The 
problem with this argument is really that nature didn't plan for house-cats 
to *be* in the first place, just like it didn't plan on chihuahuas, pugs or 
bulldogs. Can you imagine a persian cat or a chihuahua released to the 
wild, to live as "nature intended"? Cats are not ALCs. They look like them, 
but they are not half as equipped for the wild life as an actual wild cat 
is. As practice shows, when left alone to do their thing, house-cats will 
multiply like roaches, many will die at birth, diseases will be passed 
around, kittens will be bullied by other cats, the fights over the females 
will make many lose an eye... not a pretty picture. Just like many humans, 
sadly cats are terrible in family planning, and they can't be reasoned 
with, into procreating responsibly.

You have to see, that house-cats, all those loveable Persians and Ragdolls 
are a human creation, - humans are responsible for the fact they exist - 
and from the start their options in life are either: live free, breed, 
fight and die in 3-4 years, or live a long, safe but heavily controlled 
life with a human - and if you're lucky, your human will have a large back 
yard and nice cat furniture. Not much of a choice, granted, but to me the 
second option seems preferable.

That being said, for some people the decision to neuter their cat is not an 
easy one, because they acknowledge they're altering the animal's mechanism, 
not *fixing*, but *changing*, and no one who loves their cat is actually 
happy about having to put your beloved pet through this medical procedure. 
Rather they see it as a necessary evil, instead of letting the cat go 
mental when in heat and consequently get tumors... I can't help but wonder 
though, if a third option could be invented? Like, adopting 2 cats, a male 
and female, and giving the male cat a vasectomy and some sort of hormonal 
control?.. Maybe there will be some arrangement like this is the future, 
that will allow them to live full lives, yet not overproduce offspring. One 
can hope...
